nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to accurately predict the presence of heart disease from clinical and demographic features
KNN is a nonparametric, instance-based supervised learning algorithm that classifies a query by majority vote of K nearest labeled neighbors using a distance metric

The study uses a clinical dataset with features including age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, rest ECG, max heart rate, exercise-induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal and a binary target for heart disease
Data preprocessing steps include feature selection to detect informative features and weighting strategies to handle class imbalance
Model evaluation used cross-validation and metrics including sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and AUC-ROC to assess predictive performance
KNN model parameters in the experiments: K set to 10, repeats equals 3, Euclidean distance used to compute neighbor proximity
KNN requires choice of K; odd K values avoid voting ties and small K can overfit while large K can introduce noise

KNN is simple to implement, handles non-linear data, can be used for classification and regression, but is computationally expensive at classification time and sensitive to feature scaling and K choice
The dataset contains 303 individuals labeled as affected by heart disease and includes demographic and clinical risk factors used for model input
Feature importance analysis was performed to enhance interpretability and identify key factors contributing to heart disease risk
Histogram visualizations were used to examine distributions of numerical features across the dataset
Model performance was quantified by a confusion matrix yielding accuracy = (TP+TN)/(TP+FP+FN+TN) and reported accuracy of 83% for the KNN classifier
The reported experimental results support that KNN achieved promising predictive performance and interpretability for heart disease prediction in this dataset
Exploratory analysis indicated males had higher counts of diagnosed heart disease than females, associated with higher cholesterol and resting blood pressure

Conclusion: KNN is a useful, interpretable tool for heart disease risk assessment that can aid early detection and personalized risk stratification, though careful preprocessing and parameter choice are necessary
